By MARK HERTSGAARD
The Hohns Hopkins University will rescind its previous
invitation to, host and advise two high-level officials of
the military dictatorship governing Chile, according to
unofficial sources within the university. Hopkins, at the
request of the State Department, had originally agreed to
host both Christian Donosco,of the Chilean Planning
Office, IODEPLAN], and Dr. Sergio Reyes, of the
Chilean [Social] Security Association in early March,
during their stay in this country.
The university had previously offered educational
assistance to Chile's involuntary sterilization program,
which is designed for the.workers and the poor. On this
visit. Donoso and Reyes were to receive advice on how to
reorganize: their country's health care system along
private, profit-oriented lines. Such a policy, according to
a leaflet circulated by the Medical Committee for Human
Rights [MCHR] which is protesting the scheduled visit.
would "make it extremely difficult, if not impossible, for
poor and middle-income families to obtain adequate
health care."
Sources within the protesting groups reported that Or.
Richard Ross, University Vice-President for the Health
Divisions, gave a verbal guarantee yesterday that the
invitation to the two Chileans would be rescinded. Dr.
Ross was unavailable for comment to, the News-Letter.
The protesters stated that Dr. Ross' decision related only
to this specific visit and not to any other connections
between the University and the Chilean junta. Another
protesting group, the Baltimore-Chile Solidarity Group,
has criticized the Johns Hopkins Program for
International Education in Gynecology and Obstetrics
[JHPIEGO] and called for a halt to the help and training
JHPEIGO has given to the military junta's involuntary
sterilization program during the past two years.
Reyes -and Donoso had planned to visit medical
doctors, hospitals, and-health institutions throughout the
United States in their effort to dismantle Chile's
longstanding system of socializes' health care and public
health, and to replace them with a privately organized
system of medical care delivery. Leaders of Chilean
solidarity groups around the country have already been
notified about the visit. It is presumed that they will
offer the same type of resistance that led the State
Department to cut short the visit made to the United

• States last month by another representative of the
Chilean government.
The current Chilean government of General Augusto
Pinochet seized power on September 11, 1973 with the
over throw of the democratically elected, socialist
government of President Salvador Allende. Congressional
investigations later revealed that the United States'
Central Intelligence Agency and several large U.S.
corporations played an active role in the overthrow of
Allende's Popular Unity government.
The deterioration of social conditions within Chile
since the coup has been well documented by the Western
press. Even with the help of millions of dollars in U.S.
government iiid, the dictatorship has found it increasingly
difficult to maintain a stable society. Approximately one
member in six of the Chilean work force is without
employment, and malnutrition is widespread among both
children and adults. The Milton Friedman-inspired "free
market" economic policy pursued by the junta has been
largely responsible for the worsened economic
conditions.
The policy, characterized by cutbacks in government
spending, has had adverse effects on employment,
housing, public works, and most especially on the rate of
inflation. By the end of 1975, Chile's annual rate of
inflation had reached 341% — that is, the highest rate of
inflation in the world. A look at the changing pattern of
domestic income distribution during the junta's rule
reveals the essence of the "free market" policy.
According to Orlando Letelier, the slain former high
official in the Popular Unity government , "during the
last three years several billions of dollars were taken from
the pockets of wage earners and placed in those of
capitalists and landowners." /The Nation, August 28,
1976J.
It is not surprising that the Pinochet regime has had to
use brutal political repression to achieve its economic
goals. Freedom of the press and of association have been
abolished; the junta has suspended constitutional
liberties, dissolved congress and political parties, and
banned all trade unions. Figures cited in magazine of
February 10, 1977 list at 30,000 the number of Chileans
murdered by the junta, while another'100,000 have been

THE JHU GAY CAUCUS
The Johns Hopkins University Gay Caucus is an organization based
on democratic principles chartered by the Student Activities
Commission (SAC). The Gay Caucus, according to our constitution,
has the purpose of providing "a supportive and educational atmosphere
for gays and non-gays alike." With that as a firm anchor, "the JHUGC
shall institute programs for educational purposes Eano0 for the
purpose of raising political, social and personal consciousness of
the community. The membership of the JHUGC shall be -open to all...
regardless of race, religion, sex, age, political beliefs or sexual
orientation."
This is our official backgrouhd, the place to start from.
Notice that the Gay Caucus does not discriminate against non-gays. '
As a matter of fact, association with the Caucus does not brand one
as gay; rather, we seek to bring together gays and non-gays in an
atmosphere which both gives homosexual people courage to be themselves
and associate with other gay people and also allows the non-gay public
to see gays as people, not as stereotypes. To further these aims,
the Caucus sponsors coffee nouses and dances as well as planning for
speakers and films. In addition, the Caucus is represented by booths
at the daltirLore City Fair and the -Hopkins Spring Fair.
Another facet of tne Caucus is our political activity. As gays
are being accepted socially, the need for equality Under the law
becomes more and more pressing. One way we have worked for this was
an expedition to Annapolis to testify before the Maryland House of
Delegates Judiciary Committee. There were many varied groups supporting
the bills, but not enough factual evidence of discrimination to
override prejudices and convince the legislators that such legislation
was actually needed.
The Aopkins Jay Caucus believes that homosexuality is just
another way for individuals to express their love for one another,
spiritually and physically. The attitude. that love for a person of
the same sex is wrong is so pervasive that often people who feel
this attraction feel guilty. With the Gay Caucus, we are trying to
change these beliefs so that gays can accept themselves, and be
accepted as homosexuals by the general public.

In the health field, the Pinochet regime has done away
With many of the Allende era reforms which had given
the poor and working classes greater access to adequate
health care. The Allende reforms had emphasized
nuttition, immunization, and greater popular control
over health services while also realizing that a real
improvement in the health of the Chilean people would
require a total re-organization of the structure of Chilean
society. A 17-20% decline in the incidence of
malnutrition during the government of the Popular Unity
government is just one example of the success enjoyed
under such policies.
In contrast, infant mortality jumped a dramatic 18%
during the first year of the military government.
According to figures provided by the U.N. Economic
Comission on Latin America. Since the coup
approximately 8,500 health workers have been dismissed
froth the National Health Service, and it has been
reported that 40% of the people seeking health care
cannot obtain it. The Chilean Medical Association, which
is largely responsible for the administration of health care
in Chile now,is the same organization that supported the
1973 takeover. In addition, the junta's health policies ari4

Public Health Association and the National Association
of Social Workers.
The present military dictatorship in Chile is well
known for its policies of repression, terror, and social
injustice. Why, then, does Johns Hopkins University have
anything to do with the junta? Why do we aid a regime
which so flagrantly disregards human rights? As the
Medical Committee for Human Rights has said, although
"[the university] may claim that this type of technical
assistance is politically neutral,[we believe] that assisting
the Chilean visitors constitutes complicity on the
university's part in the establishment of a health care
system over which the majority of Chilean people will
have no control and which will deprive them on their
right to health care."
It is inconceivable that the Hopkins officials
responsible for accepting the request of the junta and the
State Department are unaware of the repression that is
practiced in Chile. They cannot hide behind the excuse
that technical assistance is "apolitical". Just as Hopkins
awarding of an honorary degree- to Princess Ashraf of
Iran last year constituted an implicit endorsement of the
Iranian government, so the Hopkins involvement with
Chilean health officials implies an endorsement of the
Chilean reign of terror.
While it is certainly good news that the invitations
have been reeinded, many disturbing questions remain.
Will Johns Hopkins sever all present ties with the Chilean
junta and refuse to institute any new ones? Why aren't
Hopkins' ties with all foreign governments made public?
Would the university have rescinded the invitation
without the pressure exerted by groups wuch as MCHR
and the Baltimore-Chile Solidarity Group? What benefits
have Johns Hopkins accrued from the connection with
the junta? These and other questions, as Well as reports
on health and social conditions in Chile, will be presented
in a subsequent article. [Note: those desiring more
information on the issue can contact the Solidarity

Shah exports domestic terrorism to the United States
By RUSS SMITH
It's been a year since Steven Muller's administratiOn
disgraced everyone affiliated with Hopkins by awarding
an honorary degree to Princess Ashraf, twin sister of the
notorious Shah of Iran. Before the controversy last
Spring it would be Safe to say that only a small
Percentage of the Hopkins community was aware of the
consistent human rights violations in Iran. The
conservative le Monde was prompted to state,: "Only
Chile can rival Iran for .the scope and brutality of its
repression."
By now, however, the Shah's tyrannical, iron-hand rule
has been recognized throughout the world. Amnesty
International has publicized the bloody documentation
of daily life in Iran, as have journalists and international
bodies of lawyers.
The past year has witnessed the unmasking of Iran's
ecret police SAVAK on U.S. campuses; the emergence
of the Iranian Students Association [ISA] as the most
active student political group in the country, shifty deals
between the State Department and the Shah, lecture
tours by former Iranian prisoners, and further ties
between the Shah and U.S. universities.
Since the Shah's takeover in 1953 — in a coup
engineered by the CIA — more than 300,000 people have
been in and out of Iranian prisons, all at the mercy of
ruthless SAVAK agents. Amnesty International estimates
that between 25,000 and 100,000 people are currently
Political prisoners in Iran.
But there's a new twist in SAVAK's operation. The
government of Iran is now exporting its domestic
terrorism to all points of the globe in order to sniff out
and eliminate Iranian dissidents. Participants in last year's
convocation ceremonies
will remember That part of the
security at the Lyric Theatre was provided by SAVAK.
Former Assistant Secretary of State Alfred Atherton
confirmed last September that SAVAK agents are in the
United States, monitoring the activities of insurgent
Iranian students and intellectuals. In a stormy press
conference, Henry Kissinger
denied what Atherton said,
insisting that "no Iranian intelligence personnel are
checking on individuals living in the United States."
If Kissinger had bothered to watch 60 Minutes the
Week before however, he' would have heard another
tory. Even the Shah himself would probably admit that
Ile was a bit too glib when he told Mike Wallace of 60
Atinutes "SAVAK agents are in the U.S. checking on
anybody who becomes affiliated with circles and
organizations hostile to my
country."
And more SAVAK squadrons are arriving in the U.S.
all the time. Last August , Professor Richard Cottarn of
the University of Pittsburgh was told by a State
Department official that SAVAK agents were planning to
exploit the cooperation df Mafia elements, using them to
snuff -out Iranians disloyal to the Shah. "These men," the
Professor said, "will appear as ordinary muggers and kill
the Iranians one by one."
Columnist Jack Anderson recently reported that most
of SAVAK's dirty tricks are aimed at the growing number
of Iranian students in the U.S. opposed to
the Shah's regime. One secret SAVAK document that
Anderson uncovered states "all branches should send out
in formation regarding demonstrations of dissident
Iranians, strikes, suspicious traffic, holdings of meetings,
Publishing of publications and conventions and
seminars."
Much to the chagrin of the Shah and SAVAK,the ISA
is working against the Iranian government in spots all
over the world. Of course, SAVAK wastes no time in
tracking down
the dissidents.
On November 3, the headquarters of the World
Co nfederation of Iranian Students [CISNU] in Paris was
raided by French police and all inside were arrested.
Several were immediately deported and two were charged
With the shooting of an Iranian diplomat, a man alleged
to be a
SAVAK agent. Following the shoot-out, a French
gr°1-11) called the International Brigade of Reza Rezai
claiming responsibility for the incident, thereby
disassociating
itself with the CISNU. But the charges
against the students stuck and now they are awaiting
Possible execution at the hands of SAVAK.
In Houston, on November 9, more than 90 Iranian
students
were attacked, beaten and arrested by a
?°mbination of FBI, SAVAK and Houston police while
legally protesting the French deportment of the Iranian
students in Paris.
At San Jose State University in California there's been
,a big stink over a controversial radio show programmed
°Y an Iranian student sympathetic to the Shah's
pvernment. The show has been derided by the San Jose
I_SA who say it is "extending the Shah's regime through
acist skits, decadent music, and pro-regime

announcements that arrive directly from the regime's
network." The DJ, who now tapes the program guarded

by the ISA.
ISA members stress that patriots back in Iran have the
hardest struggle to endure. "The Shah doesn't know what

those in Iran. Students are badly tortured in acid baths,
they have fingernails pulled out and so on," commented
_
an Iranian from the University of Oregon ISA.
And College administrators aren't doing
much to protect Iranian students. A high ranking
admissions officer at the University of Colorado in
Boulder takes Iranian students aside each fall, and warns
them of the consequences of being involved in the
Iranian student movement.
The ISA reports that the murder of three Americans in
Teheran last August was no freak slaying. The men were
working for Rockwell International on a multi-million
dollar surveillance unit designed to facilitate U.S.
espionage in the Persian Gulf, as well as detect dissidents
in Iran.
"The revolutionary execution of these U.S. agents is a
clear example of the growing intensity of the Iranian
peoples' struggle against foreign interference," exhorted a
national ISA release.
Recently, dissident intellectuals from Iran have been
making the lecture circuit around the U.S.. speaking
about their own experiences with SAVAK and how their

released because of international pressure. Upon coming

to this country Baraheni immediately joined the ranks of
Americans and Iranians who had formed the Committee
for Artistic and Intellectual Freedom in Iran [CAIFI], a
group instrumental in releasing him from the Shah's jail.
Baraheni said: "I was imprisoned for writing about
repression in Iran... The torture on my second day of my
arrest consisted of seventy five blows with a plaited whip
at the soles of my feet. I was whipped on the hands as
well; and the head torturer took the small finger on my
hand and broke it, saying that he was going to break my
fingers one by one, one each day."
And that's just for starters. The electrical ,prods,
injections of air bubbles and teeth-pulling comes later.

involvement in the internal affairs of Iran will trigger the
next Vietnam. The suddenly oil-rich nation, which
Amnesty International says has the "worst record of
human rights in the world," currently hosts 25,000 U.S.
military advisors, a number which is expected to climb
past 80,000 in the next few years. The U.S. has also sold
billions of dollars of arms to the Shah, making Iran
"unable to wage war without the assistance of the U.S.,"
according to a Senate study.
"If Iran becomes another Vietnam, we can be sure that

A conversation with Phil Woods
By J. D. CONSIDINE
Last Sunday, at Baltimore's Left Bank
Jazz Society, Phil Woods gave a
swinging, thoughtful, technically
devastating display of how he has
managed to win both the Reader's and

pressure to go before the local community. What they
should keep in mind, though, is the probability that both
federal and local governments could start acting for them -that is, regulating them -- if their current quietness prevails.

Sex discrimination at Maryland
A sex discrimination suit with far-reaching
implications for the position of women in academia
and the workworld in general is currently being
argued in the United States District Court in
Baltimore, Maryland. Dr. Margaret Cussler, an
associate professor of sociology at the University of
Maryland, has charged five past and present
University of Maryland administrators with failure
to promote her to the rank of full professor and to
grant her reasonable salary increases because she is a
woman. Cussler's eight-year effort to receive salary
and rank commensurate with her qualifications and
performance finally reached the federal court in
November and the jury trial is expected to last at
least through March of this year.
Professor Cussler earned her Ph.D. from
Harvard-Radcliffe in 1943 and first joined the
sociology faculty at the University of Maryland in
1947. In 1962 she became the first woman
sociologist promoted to the rank of associate
professor at the University. She is a past president
of the District of Columbia Sociological Society and
the recipient of nearly a score of research grants,
fellowships, and other awards. The author of The
Woman Executive, Cussler has authored or
co-authored three other books and several articles,
notes, and other writings in various professional
journals. She has also written and co-produced three
sociological films. Additional information about her
creative and scholarly work is summarized in
American Men and Women of Science and Who's
Who in American Women.

The University denied Cussler promotion to the
rank of full professor in 1968, 1970 and 1971. The
case has been investigated by several committees,
including two university faculty committees, and all
have found in her favor. Her credentials have been
reviewed and compared with those of male full
professors in the same department by a number of
noted sociologists, all of whom have judged her to
be equal to or better than her male counterparts.
Equal justice under law is difficult to achieve
unless the private citizen has funds adequate to
challenge the resources of the state. Throughout the
history of the Cussler case, unequal resources have
proven to be a major issue. The defense, which was
originally being handled by University lawyers, has

since been augmented by the State Attorney
General's Office which, in turn, hired a private legal
firm for additional legal and staff support.
Knowing full well that the longer the trial lasts,
the more expensive it becomes, the defense has
employed another tactic in the form of delaying the
progress of the trial, first by keeping it out of court
for four years and now by unreasonably prolonging
the questioning of witnesses and requesting frequent
recesses.
Dr. Cussler is being represented by Sylvia
Roberts, an extremely capable and noted attorney
who specializes in sex discrimination cases.
Nonetheless, because they lack access to the State
Treasury, Cussler and Roberts have not been able to
afford such basic resources as a rechnical staff, legal
assistants, or clerical help (except for one part-time
secretary). Also because of lack of funds, the
number of expert (and other) witnesses they have
been able to introduce has been limited due to the
expenses of travel and lodging.

One of the major Claims of the University
administrators is that they are powerless to interfere
with employment and promotion procedures within
an academic department regardless of whether the
departmental policies and practices are
discriminatory. If this claim is upheld, it would
mean that universities are free to ignore federal laws
prohibiting discrimination. The consequences for
fair and equal treatment based on merit are
frightening.
The Cussler case is one of the few cases of sex
discrimination filed by an individual and it may be
the first jury trial held on a charge of sex
discrimination in employment against a college of
university. If Cussler wins, she could become one of
the first women to Lceive monetary compensation
for damages from a university for sex
discrimination.

A project's physical and biological containment levels

proposal (if the project is to receive NIH grant money,
which most do) to an NIH review group. In between
stands the local biohazards committee of the university,
responsible for reviewing and approving the applications.
At Hopkins, the 14-member biohazards committee is
headed by Dr. Roger Herriot of the Med School, and
includes a couple non-science-oriented members (but no
students, however). Described as "fairly aggressive" by
one biology professor, the committee "tries to be
reasonably conservative in our estimates without
hamstringing research," according to Ballantine. The
Provost's office oversees the whole affair: Assistant
Provost Richard Zdanis stated that "the charge to the
biohazards committee is to make sure the level of
containment for the research is appropriate to the
experiment being conducted. As long as the levels are in
accordance with the guidelines, we're satisfied."
All those at Hopkins involved in recombinant DNA
research, from the professors to the committee members,
are naturally satisfied to work within the NIH guidelines.
Those with a vested interest in the research must be
expected to support their work—no one in the Biology
Department (or in related fields and at the Med School,

Sex discrimination at Maryland
A sex discrimination suit with far-reaching
implications for the position of women in academia
and the workworld in general is currently being
argued in the United States District Court in
Baltimore, Maryland. Dr. Margaret Cussler, an
associate professor of sociology at the University of
Maryland, has charged five past and present
University of Maryland administrators with failure
to promote her to the rank of full professor and to
grant her reasonable salary increases because she is a
woman. Cussler's eight-year effort to receive salary
and rank commensurate with her qualifications and
performance finally reached the federal court in
November and the jury trial is expected to last at
least through March of this year.
Professor Cussler earned her Ph.D. from
Harvard-Radcliffe in 1943 and first joined the
sociology faculty at the University of Maryland in
1947. In 1962 she became the first woman
sociologist promoted to the rank of associate
professor at the University. She is a past president
of the District of Columbia Sociological Society and
the recipient of nearly a score of research grants,
fellowships, and other awards. The author of The
Woman Executive, Cussler has authored or
co-authored three other books and several articles,
notes, and other writings in various professional
journals. She has also written and co-produced three
sociological films. Additional information about her
creative and scholarly work is summarized in
American Men and Women of Science and Who's
Who in American Women.

The University denied Cussler promotion to the
rank of full professor in 1968, 1970 and 1971. The
case has been investigated by several committees,
including two university faculty committees, and all
have found in her favor. Her credentials have been
reviewed and compared with those of male full
professors in the same department by a number of
noted sociologists, all of whom have judged her to
be equal to or better than her male counterparts.
Equal justice under law is difficult to achieve
unless the private citizen has funds adequate to
challenge the resources of the state. Throughout the
history of the Cussler case, unequal resources have
proven to be a major issue. The defense, which was
originally being handled by University lawyers, has

since been augmented by the State Attorney
General's Office which, in turn, hired a private legal
firm for additional legal and staff support.
Knowing full well that the longer the trial lasts,
the more expensive it becomes, the defense has
employed another tactic in the form of delaying the
progress of the trial, first by keeping it out of court
for four years and now by unreasonably prolonging
the questioning of witnesses and requesting frequent
recesses.
Dr. Cussler is being represented by Sylvia
Roberts, an extremely capable and noted attorney
who specializes in sex discrimination cases.
Nonetheless, because they lack access to the State
Treasury, Cussler and Roberts have not been able to
afford such basic resources as a rechnical staff, legal
assistants, or clerical help (except for one part-time
secretary). Also because of lack of funds, the
number of expert (and other) witnesses they have
been able to introduce has been limited due to the
expenses of travel and lodging.

One of the major Claims of the University
administrators is that they are powerless to interfere
with employment and promotion procedures within
an academic department regardless of whether the
departmental policies and practices are
discriminatory. If this claim is upheld, it would
mean that universities are free to ignore federal laws
prohibiting discrimination. The consequences for
fair and equal treatment based on merit are
frightening.
The Cussler case is one of the few cases of sex
discrimination filed by an individual and it may be
the first jury trial held on a charge of sex
discrimination in employment against a college of
university. If Cussler wins, she could become one of
the first women to Lceive monetary compensation
for damages from a university for sex
discrimination.
